title: Advanced Cost Accounting Theory and Techniques
headline: Learn and discover all about advanced cost accounting theory and its techniques in this free online course.
description: This cost accounting course provides an overview of advanced costing theory and its techniques. You will learn to classify costs and recognise cost behaviour. This insight will enable you to analyse cost-volume-profit dynamics and report on activity-based costs. In addition, you will be able to apply your understanding of cost elements in other value-adding organisational activities such as budgeting and variance analysis.
courseDescription:
This advanced cost accounting course covers the basic definitions and cost theories that provide a granular understanding of its behaviour. In addition, we will discuss the techniques used to classify and analyse cost elements, report on cost structures and the effect of changes in activity levels. We will guide the learners through marginal costing concepts and the application of marginal and fixed cost classifications in profit-volume analysis. We will further analyse the marginal costing theory by incorporating an evaluation of alternative situations based on a type of marginal cost referred to as relevant costs. 

Once you understand cost classification and behaviour, traditional costing methods such as process costing can be applied more sophisticatedly, increasing the relevance of management reports and the value of insights gained. In addition, we will investigate the activity-based costing (ABC) principles. Finally, you will understand how to contrast traditional costing methods with activity-based methods and recognise situations where one method is preferred over another.   

Course participants will learn concepts and techniques used to recognise and measure different types of costs. Learners will also gain strategic acuity in the context of costs and the interaction between cost behaviour and organisational objectives. Enrol for free and start your journey towards advanced managerial insight.

  • Fixed cost
    A cost incurred for an accounting period that, within certain output or turnover limits, tends to be
    unaffected by fluctuations in the activity level. - CIMA official terminology

    Variable cost
    The cost varies with a measure of activity. - CIMA official terminology

    Semi-variable cost
    A cost contains both fixed and variable components and is thus partly affected by a change in the activity level.
    - CIMA official terminology

  • Terminology 

  • Cost units, cost centres and cost objects
    Costs can be attributed to cost units, cost centres or cost objects. A cost unit can be anything for which it is possible to ascertain the cost. A cost centre is a responsibility centre used as a collecting place for costs.

    Classification of costs
    There are two main cost classifications: element or nature.

    Classification of costs according to behaviour
    Costs can be classified into three types of behaviour: fixed costs, variable costs, and semi-variable costs.

    Classification of costs according to element
    Classifying costs according to their element involves grouping costs based on the elements of production, i.e. materials, labour, and overheads.

    Classification of costs according to nature (direct and indirect)
    Classification of costs according to their nature could be a distinction between direct and indirect costs. 

  • Terminology 

  • Direct cost
    A direct cost is a cost that can be directly and incrementally attributable to a unit of output.

    Indirect cost
    An indirect cost can be incremental but cannot be directly attributable to a unit of output.

    Classification of costs according to nature (product and period)
    Classification of costs according to their nature could be a distinction between product and period costs.

    Product cost
    A product cost is a cost that can be directly and incrementally attributable to a unit of output and is directly proportionate to activity level.

    Period cost
    Period costs are independent of activity level and accrue on a duration basis. 

  • Terminology 

  • The purpose of management accounting
    The purpose of management accounting can be defined as the activity of planning, controlling, and decision-making.

    Planning
    The planning phase establish the objectives of an organisation, i.e. what they are trying to achieve, and developing strategies. Management accountants create budgets that explain the impacts of different courses of action. These budgets are financial plans of what will occur based on given assumptions.

    Control
    Control is the process of monitoring, measuring, evaluating and correcting results achieved to enable the organisation to reach its objectives.

    Decision making
    Managers at different organisational levels make different types of decisions: operational, tactical, and strategic. Decision-making involves the evaluation of different courses of action using a decision-making framework based on predetermined objectives and measurement criteria. i.e. choosing a course of action that satisfies an objective function in the most effective way taking account of predetermined measurement criteria.

  • Absorption Costing 

  • Absorption costing
    Traditional absorption costing aims to determine the full production cost per unit.

    Traditional absorption costing principles can be applied with varying levels of sophistication, ranging from simple process costing situations to complex activity-based costing and management.

    The principles of absorption costing include concepts such as directly attributable and incremental production costs and non-production costs.

  • Marginal Costing 

  • Marginal cost
    Marginal cost can be defined as the part of the cost of one unit of output that would be avoided if the unit of output was not produced or would increase if one extra unit were produced. Marginal or direct costs include direct material, direct labour, and variable overhead.

    Marginal costing is a costing method which charges units of production with variable costs while expensing period costs. As a result, only marginal costs end up in inventory and thus are not in line with IAS2 Inventories, which requires a reasonable absorption of production-related overheads.

    Full cost-plus pricing
    There may be different interpretations of what is included in the cost element of cost-plus pricing.

    In some circumstances, the full cost may include directly attributable overheads; in others, a marginal approach may be more appropriate. When Using a full cost plus method, the selling price for a product is calculated as the full cost plus a percentage mark-up.

    Selling price = Full cost per unit of output x (1 + mark-up percentage)

  • Marginal Costing 

  • Marginal cost-plus pricing
    Marginal cost is the same as a variable cost. However, a larger mark-up percentage is required to be profitable in the long term when setting the selling price using a marginal costing approach.

    Marginal costing is useful in pricing and production strategies. When using a marginal cost-plus method, the selling price for a product is calculated as the marginal cost plus a percentage mark-up.

    Selling price = Marginal cost per unit of output x (1 + mark-up percentage)

    Target return on capital
    The mark-up percentage reflects the total required return on investment in a product expressed as a total investment at a batch, product or facility level.

    The required return on investment takes account of different factors such as interest rate, duration risk and capital risk.

    Target return on investment in product = Total investment in product x Target rate of return.

  • Costing Systems 

  • Costing systems
    The purpose of costing is to calculate the cost of each cost unit of an organisation's products. While different methods could be employed, the overall aim is to record all the costs relating to a defined output. The two main types of costing systems are specific order costing; and continuous costing.

    Specific order costing
    The main example of specific order costing is job costing, where costs are attributed to a specific job.

    Continuous costing
    A series of similar products or services for which costs are collected and averaged over the number of products or services produced to calculate a cost per-unit amount.

  • Joint Costs

  • Joint product costing
    Products may be produced simultaneously in the same process before being separated for sale or further processing. These products are known as joint products, and the separation point is the split-off point.

    Common process costs
    Joint or common costs are the total of the raw material, labour, and overhead costs incurred in the common process up to the split-off point. Joint costs cannot usually be directly attributed to individual joint products. Therefore arbitrary allocations may have to be used instead.

    Joint products and by-products
    The nature of process costing is that the process incurs joint costs and often produces more than one product. The output of a common process may be referred to as joint products or by-products. Joint products are all the main products, whereas by-products are incidental to the main products.

  • Joint Costs

  • Joint products
    Joint products are two or more products produced by the same process and separated in processing, each having a sufficiently high saleable value relative to the other distinct outputs of the common process to be classified as a joint product.

    By-products
    A by-product is the output of some value produced incidentally in producing something else.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Joint Costs

  • Methods of joint cost apportionment
    There are many ways in which joint costs can be attributed to products, such as physical measurement, market value at the point of separation, or net realisable value/net relative sales value.

    These methods will result in different inventory valuations and recorded profits.

    Accounting for joint products
    Joint costs require apportionment between products for inventory valuation purposes. The main basis for apportionment is the physical measurement, market value, and net realisable value.

    Accounting for by-products
    Proceeds from the sale of by-products may be treated as pure profit even if further processing is required. Alternatively, the net revenue from sales may be accounted for as a reduction in the cost of the main products.

  • Joint Costs 

  • Physical measurement
    Joint costs can be apportioned to the units of the output of each joint product. All joint costs are not incurred equally; such joint costs can be separated and apportioned by introducing weighting factors. Alternatively, a technical estimate of relative usage can be used.

    Physical measurement - a unit of measure
    If the unit of measurement is different (e.g. litres and kilos), some method should be used to express them in a common unit.

    Market value
    Joint costs can be apportioned based on the market value of each joint product at the point of separation. The effect is to make each product appear to be equally profitable.

    Net realisable value
    Further processing costs are deducted from market values before joint costs are apportioned.  

  • Joint Costs 

  • Joint costs in decision making
    Processing decisions are focused on total common costs and revenues, while further processing decisions are based on incremental costs and revenues.

    Processing decisions
    The basis of common cost apportionment is irrelevant to the common processing decision—the process as a whole needs to be profitable based on total costs and revenues.

    Further processing decisions
    Further processing decisions are based on incremental revenue. Positive incremental revenue is the minimum requirement to further the process. Therefore, incremental revenues should always be available. If common processing costs are accurately allocated, an incremental contribution can be calculated along with further limiting factor figures.

  • Activity-Based-Costing

  • Activity-Based-Costing (ABC)
    Activity-based costing is an approach to costing an organisation's outputs. It is a form of absorption costing that base absorption of cost on the activity of cost drivers. Costs are allocated to activity centres or cost pools.

    When is ABC relevant?
    Activity-based costing provide more accurate information about product costs when: indirect costs are high relative to direct costs; products or services are complex; products or services are customised to customer specifications, and product lines with large differences in volumes produced and sold.

    The implications of switching to ABC
    Pricing; pricing can be based on more accurate data, improving pricing decisions. Sales strategy; Realistic product costs enable an organisation to execute pricing and other marketing strategies with more precision.

    Cost driver
    A cost driver is a unit of individual activity that consumes resources and causes cost. An alternative definition of a cost driver is a factor influencing the cost level.

  • Throughput Accounting 

  • Throughput accounting
    Throughput accounting is similar to marginal costing but can be used to make longer-term decisions about capacity and production mix.

    Under throughput accounting, the only cost deemed to relate to the output volume is the direct material cost. All other costs (including direct labour) are deemed to be fixed. These fixed costs may be called Total Factory Costs (TFC).

    Throughput contribution
    Throughput contribution = (Revenue-Total direct material costs)

    Conversion costs
    A distinction can be made between direct material and other manufacturing costs. These other manufacturing costs are referred to as conversion costs.

    Conversion costs include a mix of direct and indirect manufacturing costs, such as direct labour and factory overheads.
